Fields.DialogueText: I don't think I've ever seen the crew stepping this lively. There seems to be more enthusiasm than normal across the fleet.
Of course, Captain! It's one thing to be fighting monsters bent on the destruction of your world, but it's entirely another to know the world is behind you.
For the first time, our folks aren't just a ragtag group of sailors. They're the saviors of the world, and that'll light a fire under anyone.
I can't argue with that. How long do you think it will last? I could get used to this.
It will last a while, but it will become the new normal soon enough. That's why I keep crafting new ways to motivate my sailors.

Fields.MenuText: The effect you have on the men and women of the Fleet cannot be overstated.
I never thought throwing fancy parties could have helped us this much.
I still think we'd be better off devoting our resources to the battle at hand, but I can't deny you've been effective.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure you could do it if you put your mind to it, darling. You're quite the flatterer.
What, did you think they were frivolous? I would never be a part of them if they were a waste of time.
It's quite the good thing I don't listen to you, isn't it? Who knows where we'd be if we were all so dour.
There's the alarm. I suppose talk of parties will need to be shelved for the time being.
Don't worry, I'm always planning the next one in the back of my mind. Now let's show them what for, boys and girls!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Well, having seen evidence of your success firsthand, I can only hope you continue to put your mind to this.
Augusta, I wanted to talk to you. There have been some complaints from the sailors.
What? And they complained to you and not to me? Why, I am insulted they would go behind my back like this!
Apparently they did come to you, but you didn't take their complaints seriously. It's about the penguins.
Oh, no! Has something happened to my little babies? I hope no one has hurt the precious little dears!
Actually, I've got reports that the penguins have been taking over rooms and stealing food. And when there were complaints, you just made all the penguins deck officers.
Well, that certainly put an end to the complaints, didn't it? Now the penguins can handle things themselves.

Fields.MenuText: Making animals officers is the stupidest thing I've ever heard of.
Making an officer in charge of their own complaints is the stupidest thing I've ever heard of.
Letting animals loose on a ship is the stupidest thing I've ever heard of.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, hush. For all we know, Rome would still be an empire today if Incitatus had been made Consul.
I don't see why. We can trust them to act with the grace, decorum, and equipoise that befits their new station.
I don't see why. We have cats to chase the mice, don't we? The dolphins swim alongside us. It is mutually beneficial.
We aren't through with this conversation.
Of course! We still need to discuss the little dears' uniforms!
Or maybe we'll all be sunk. I just have to look on the bright side. Although I guess the penguins would still be fine...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Get back into position! The enemy fleet is almost on top of us!
Now, what's all this fuss about, Captain? I can't think it becomes you to be this flustered.
Two of the support ships are out of position. They're steaming ahead too fast, and they're going to be vulnerable.
Ah, they look like Germans. Let me talk to them, Captain! I'll have them falling in line in a jiffy.
... Gut, viel Glück! All right, Captain - they should be back in position now.
Excellent work, Augusta. I didn't know you spoke German, by the way. A handy skill to have.
Why wouldn't I speak German? Speak sense, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't see that you'd ever been to Germany, so I was surprised you picked it up.
I should have expected it. You seem to speak every other language as well.
I'm just never going to comment on another one of your skills. How would you feel about that, hmm?

Fields.DialogueText: "Never been to Germany!" Oh, I do laugh, Captain! Such silly things you say.
Goodness no, Captain. I barely speak a handful. They really aren't that hard to learn, though.
That seems very sound to me; it's not like I am particularly noteworthy. Really, anyone could do what I do if they put their minds to it.
All right, we're nearing the engagement distance. The time for accolades is over.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I received your most recent party invitation. I noticed this one was not delivered by a penguin.
Oh, of course not, Captain! That wouldn't be the least bit proper!
I'm glad you've finally come around, Augusta. That was definitely starting to get out of hand.
Of course, Captain! This is a ball for the whole crew, after all, and it does not behoove Deck Officers to invite the common sailor.
It smacks of subservience for one thing, and it's really the purview of a manservant or batman.
Augusta, these are penguins. They are legitimately animals, and you really need to stop this.
Captain, you best watch your tongue. Even if they are currently your inferiors, such talk about officers could damage the morale of the Fleet.

Fields.MenuText: I just want this madness to end.
All right, fine. I will no longer speak ill so candidly of any member of the officer corps.
I can speak ill of whatever I choose, especially if it is disrupting the fleet.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't imagine what you mean, Captain. Do I detect a note of sourness?
I think you'll find this to the benefit of the Fleet as a whole, Captain. An atmosphere of respect goes a long way.
Harrumph, I see how it is. Don't expect me to have any sympathy for you when you come calling for assistance from the officer corps.
Let's talk about this later. Or maybe never.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I was just delivered an intelligence report. After not seeing you around the ship for some time.
Leaving aside that it was delivered by a dog, how accurate is this information?
You should treat Ensign Fluffy Scruff Face with the respect that befits his position in the chain of command, however low it is.
And that information is entirely accurate. The enemy fleet is moving into the waters around Italy soon.
I suppose that means we should be after them. We can't just let them ravage the Italian countryside.
I should say not! Just think what it would do to the palettes of the world!

Fields.MenuText: I feel like we should be concerned for a few more reasons than that.
For the sake of your party's snack trays, I suppose we shall move to assist.
All right, let's just get a move on. And someday you'll need to explain how you keep managing not to get caught.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course! If they sink Venice, I'll never have my portrait painted on its banks! What a blow that would be.
And the drink selection, you utter barbarian. I swear, darling, you'd be happy eating pig slop if it came in a nicer color.
Respect my wily ways, Captain. A true southern Belle can always take care of herself.
All right, inform the crew of our new course. I can only imagine we'll be hitting stragglers on our way in.
But of course, darling! Don't worry, we'll have no trouble with them.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
So this is the party you threw for the crew? I wasn't expecting it to be quite so... rambunctious.
Oh, well, my lovelies do love to blow off steam, and we invited several of the other crews to make this a proper hootenanny.
Someone just broke a chair over that man's head. I think you're understating a little bit. This can't be healthy.
Oh, honey, I know you're an officer, but you should know the ways of the common folk. They do like a rousing day now and then.
Rousing? This is anarchy. Part of the mess is on fire!
Oh, Mr. Fort, do be a dear and put that out, would you? Thank you, sweetie.

Fields.MenuText: The level of control you have over your crew, even in this anarchy, is impressive.
I still don't understand how you get away with all of this. They seem to enjoy listening to you.
At least the animals aren't involved in this for once.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, hardly, darling. This is just a little friendly exertion. Think of it as football without the expense of a ball.
Whatever do you mean, darling? My boys and girls simply respect my opinion when given.
Of course not, hun! They're all officers, and it would not behoove them to be involved in such a wild day.
All right, all right, I think I hear the alarm. We're catching up with the fleet. Let me get some officers in here to break this up.
Now, now, dears, the good Captain has found us a fight. Let's not disappoint after all that hard work.
@BATTLE
All right, we've got a pretty big fight ahead of us. It looks like the Morgana fleet has been raiding up and down the coast.
Raiding? Darling, whatever are they taking from these poor souls?
Raiding was a poor choice of words. They seem to be sinking moored vessels and shelling the coast.
Those monsters! They're destroying the vineyards! I'll show those varmints what for!
They're also hitting industrial areas, but yes, the vineyards have taken a hit. We need to start securing the waters, but Italy is not shaped well for the task.
We shall simply have to follow the coast line and root them out of every winery! I mean... every bay!

Fields.MenuText: It's good to know your heart is in this battle, Augusta. I don't know what we'd do without you.
That's more or less the plan, actually. Even if we chase them into open ocean, that's still a victory.
Yes, we can stop to restock provisions while we're here. I was already planning on it.

Fields.DialogueText: Die in disarray and terror, most likely. It's a useful skill for the enemy, but not so much for yourself.
Lovely, Captain! We shall simply see to it that they never threaten the hardworking peasants of Italy again.
Oh, well, if you're offering, I would love to take a trip up near the base of the peninsula.
All right, we're coming up on a likely spot, so that's enough talk for now. We'll get the strategy meeting going again soon.
Of course, darling. Come to me whenever you need help.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right, this is going well so far, but we really need to start coordinating with the men and women along the coast if we want more accurate information.
Why, Captain! You do know I could get you any information you need, don't you, darling?
Yes, yes, we're all impressed by your abilities of subterfuge and deception, but not even you can watch the whole coastline at once.
I begrudgingly cede you the point, Captain. So, what do we do about it?
Well, Italy has listening posts and watch towers, so next time we stop to resupply, we'll try to make contact.
With luck, we'll be able to use their men and technology to help us keep an eye on the Morgana fleets.
That's brilliant, Captain, but what if they decide they have better things to do with their time than help us?

Fields.MenuText: Well, then... I guess you're throwing another party.
I'm sure we can impress upon them the dangers of their current situation.
Then a large number of people are going to die before we can run off the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: Why, Captain, you do care. Let me dust off some of my Italy plans, and I'll start preparing.
I feel we can make a few reasonable points, yes. You are ever the persuasive speaker, Captain.
Let's make sure it doesn't come to that grim approximation, Captain.
*ALARM*
Crew to action stations!
@BATTLE
We need to resupply soon. These battles have been coming fast, and we're running low on ammunition and men.
I do apologize, Captain. I've been trying to arrange things with my friends around the world, but there have been issues.
Apparently there is some irregularity among the Italian trains, and they are having trouble moving freight in a timely manner.
You're saying Mussolini doesn't have the trains running on time? That might not be a popular sentiment in these parts.
Well, no matter. In the meantime, we'll have to meet with the local commanders and get what they can spare.
Oooh, I have some thoughts on where we can head ashore. I'd be happy as a cat in a field of one legged chickens in northern Italy.

Fields.MenuText: This isn't a sightseeing tour, Augusta. We are here to work, and we need to focus on industrial or military areas.
You know, I think that can be arranged. We're headed up the coast as it is.
We'll go where we can. The Fleet doesn't benefit from indulging our personal preferences.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I don't see why we can't do both. And it would be an excellent experience for my sailors to see some culture.
Lovely, darling, lovely! You've made me the happiest girl in the fleet!
Of course, Captain. The needs of the Fleet always come first.
I think we'll have to talk more about this in the future.
Of course! I'll draw up some contingency parties after the battle.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right, I think I've managed to pinpoint a couple of good places to resupply. Here, here, and here.
Ah, lovely choices, Captain, lovely choices. I'll send my card ahead and begin planning for our arrival.
This isn't just a pleasure cruise, Augusta. And besides, if the Morganas catch wind of our movements, they'll ambush us.
So they won't find out! Don't worry so much, darling! Besides, this way they'll have our supplies ready.
As long as those are the Fleet's supplies and not just your supplies, I have no problem trusting you on this.
I'm hurt, Captain! Why would you ever have occasion to question my decisions?

Fields.MenuText: Because you disappear without warning all the time.
Because sometimes you seem more interested in throwing parties than fighting a war.
Because penguins stole my best pair of dress shoes two days ago. While I was wearing them.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but I always come back with useful information.
Slander, sir! I am nothing if not fastidious in my devotion to our cause!
So that's where the little darlings got those! You can have them back, assuming you don't mind destroying the poor dears' nest.
We'll talk about it later. We have another engagement in a matter of minutes.
Making resupply all the more relevant, lovely Captain!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
So this is the first harbor? I must say, it... is a bit more rustic than I imagined.
Oh, come on. It's gorgeous. But I don't suppose the living is easy.
I doubt you can get a decent cocktail for five hundred miles. No, thank you. This is not for me.
Fair enough. The important thing is whether or not they can lay hands on the supplies we need.
As long as we can keep ourselves fed, our guns firing, and maybe even get a few more sailors, I don't care where they live.
That's good, because they seem to live in shacks that were getting a bit run down back in Napoleon's day.
And I despair of the odds of civilized grooming.

Fields.MenuText: Beggars can't be choosers. And we are literally beggars right now, Augusta.
That's no way to talk about your new shipmates, Augusta. Show a modicum of decorum.
Don't worry, we'll have them wipe their feet before they come aboard.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I bet they are too. So we can at least be a little choosy.
How dare you, Captain? I will treat them with the charity and generosity as befits my station as soon as they are within earshot.
I may have my lovelies hose them down on the docks if it's all the same to you.
Hold that thought. It looks like we aren't the only ones with designs on this dock.
Well let's see these varmints off! These are my crude and uncouth future sailors!
@BATTLE
Augusta, the negotiations are not going very well. We may need to have you throw that party after all.
Oh, no! Are they refusing to give us supplies? I had thought better of them.
No, it's not that. The mayor is willing to share what they have, but there's some conflict about the watch towers.
It seems like there's some officer or another who is refusing to share resources with the us. Something about security.
Well this is the time when all people should be coming together, so I will see to it that they see the error of their curmudgeonly ways.
I knew I could count on you, Augusta. With the added intel, we can really help these people.
I am always willing to do my bit for the cause, darling. It's simply who I am!

Fields.MenuText: It's good to have you on our side. I shudder to think what a party planner of your magnitude could do for the Morganas.
And the Fleet is thankful for your support, Augusta.
I'm just happy to see all of your skills coming in handy, not just the scouting prowess.

Fields.DialogueText: Why, I'd have the governments of the world eating out of their hands in months. Not that I would help them.
Of course, honey. Do tell the Fleet they are ever so welcome.
All of my skills are important and my prowess is unmatched in any area. And don't you forget it.
Oh, the alarm! It looks like those women are trying to push into the bay again. Let's see them off, shall we?
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Captain, I had a talk with a few of the locals that I invited aboard for an afternoon soiree, and I think I discovered something.
The man who is blocking our use of the listening posts isn't Italian, he's German. That's the source of our issues.
What's a German doing commanding Italians in Italy? That's a bit of an odd circumstance.
I'm inclined to agree, but I rather think we've discovered the source of the contention with the use of the posts.
More than likely, he is under orders not to disclose the location or strength of his forces in the region. I can imagine why - I'm fairly conspicuously American.
And proud of it, I might add.
I don't like it, but we'll deal with the reality of the situation.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think you can convince him to help us? We can't stay here much longer.
I suppose we're proceeding with the party plan, then? We need to convince him to help us.
We just need to convince him of our neutrality and remind him of the greater threats at sea.

Fields.DialogueText: I can convince anyone of anything, Darling, and don't you forget it.
I was always going to throw the party, Darling. Just because this isn't the ideal location doesn't mean I'm giving up.
Ah, sweet reason. That's one of two ways to get to the heart of any German. The other, I've found, is beer.
Well, I trust in your abilities. Let's head out and check the picket ships. I get the feeling we'll have trouble soon.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
This is a very informal party, given my experience with you. A party for officers at least.
Well, I wanted the locals to be able to unwind.
Moving on. Have you gotten a chance to talk to our mysterious German yet?
I have, but he is being very firm about the strategic necessity of his command, and how he cannot compromise it.
I assume you have a plan, and that plan involves the Fleet movements I can see but don't remember ordering?
Don't worry, sweetie - you will have made a wise decision. I know what I'm doing, after all.

Fields.MenuText: I really have to draw the line at issuing false orders in my name. That's actually a security risk.
I assume you're pulling the same trick twice? I do hope it works just as well.
I can't wait to see the fireworks. There's a Morgana fleet coming for us, I trust.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh pshaw, now that you know I can do it, it's nothing to worry about, right?
Oh, no, this is obviously a different entertainment for a different crowd. I would never repeat myself.
Now how would I know that? We'll be in position soon, incidentally.
Now, my esteemed guests, if you would look to port, you will see the hated Morganas, from whom we will protect you.
All right, I get it. I'm headed to my station.
@BATTLE
I just got confirmation that the German officer has agreed to lend us the assistance of his listening post and to push the request upstairs.
Well, that sounds promising.
It definitely is. It's not perfect, but it'll go a long way towards better defending Italy.
Thank you, Augusta.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you were able to talk some sense into the gentleman.
Do you know why he was being so secretive? It's not as though we would have asked for the location of the posts.
I hope his recommendation counts for something with his superiors. I'd hate to go through this whole dog and pony show again.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, darling. What man can resist doing a favor for little old me, after all?
Well, I doubt he wants anyone to know he's here, let alone how closely they are working together.
I believe you mean dog and penguin show, Captain. Do give credit where it is due.
You never explained how you learned German, Augusta. Are there a lot of Germans back home?
More than a few. But really, I learned in honor of the woman herself, Princess Augusta.
Is that a fact? I'd like to hear more... except, that's the alarm, isn't it?
I can't be teaching you history when there's a war on, Captain.
@BATTLE
It looks like the German has managed to convince a few of his friends to help us. Whatever you told him seems to have worked.
Of course it did. Familial humanity works on most people, I have found. And that's what we're fighting for, after all.
But I assume you had a specific thought? What happened to make you so thankful?
We're getting reports of major movements throughout the area, even if the reports are sparse. It's enough for us to begin planning a defense.
I've also got a good port to resupply at, according to the information we have. It should have a wealth of materials, munitions, and men.
The only thing of interest is that it, too, is controlled largely by German forces. It's not an occupation, exactly. They're just... there.
That's good news, even if it is very strange. I trust we are making with all speed for that port?
Not just yet. We have a few detours along the way, and we might be able to make a few more stops.

Fields.MenuText: I trust you won't have any objections to a leisurely cruise to ports where the wine flows freely?
Hopefully we can meet with a few more of these listening post commanders along the way.
I assume you'll be wanting to throw a few more parties as we travel?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not, darling. I assume they can spare a few casks for the war effort.
I'm sure I can make quite the impression on them as well.
Perhaps a few small ones, but I need to plan something big for the location of our resupply.
Well, be thinking about it. We've got a few more engagements to push through before we get there.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I have a question about your history, Augusta. It's been bothering me and I hope you don't mind.
A Lady never reveals her age, even if it is a matter of public record, Captain.
Not that, I was wondering about the Princess Augusta you mentioned. Your namesake once removed.
Oh her, darling? Whyever for?

Fields.MenuText: I want to get to know the men and women under my command, and she sounded important to you.
Your repeated non-answers have piqued my curiosity.
Just curious. I don't talk about princesses very much.

Fields.DialogueText: She's an important lesson, at the very least, if only as a cautionary tale.
They'll do that, I suppose. Really, she's more of a cautionary tale for young ladies than anything.
And I think about them entirely too much.
So you learned German in her honor, you said? I would've thought you'd favor the British parts of her story.
Oh, all the drama with King George and Queen Charlotte? Darling, you know I hate to gossip when the people I'd be gossiping about have been dead for more than a century.
So... the German studies? She came from German stock, she spoke German, she...
Actually, her generation grew up with English. I don't think she ever made much too effort to learn German, even when she became Duchess of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel.
Okay. I'm missing something.
Oh, look, there's the alarm. Action stations, everyone.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
We should be reaching a resupply point soon. I'm not sure what the enemy disposition will be - these fellows haven't been responding to us.
There are a few of those wretched girls patrolling the waters outside, a bit close even. But nothing we can't handle.
And I assume you pulled off some masterful piece of scouting to ascertain this information?
Oh, no, we caught a fishing boat on radio earlier today, and Petty Officer Romano learned Italian on his mother's knee.
Oh, well, that also works, I suppose. It shouldn't be too hard to push in for our supplies then, and they'll probably be thankful for our arrival.
Really, darling, when will you get over your frankly superstitious attitude towards my competency?

Fields.MenuText: Said the glorious ship spirit.
When you stop being supernaturally good, I suppose.
Maybe the attitude is just directed at you in general, and not just the things you do well.

Fields.DialogueText: That is actually a fair point, sweetie. Carry on.
Ah, I'll strive to make a few mistakes then, shall I? I suppose if it makes you happy...
Impossible. Everything I do is done well. How could there be a divide?
Let's see if your powers still extend to the offensive. Let's drive these ships off.
Of course, darling. I'll send them to the bottom with flair.
@BATTLE
I have a very bad feeling about this. Where is everyone?
Not that I demand to be worshipped, but I'm inclined to agree. Shouldn't there be at least an official greeting?
We'll send away teams. We need to resupply if we can, and if we can't, I want to know what happened here.
Do you smell that, Captain? It smells like burning wood. I think I see flames up the road.

Fields.MenuText: Has the war reached this part of Italy? Are we looking at the aftermath of a battle?
Did the Morganas do this? It seems too directed and thorough to be their work.
We need to be careful. Let's put some men ashore to get supplies and then leave.

Fields.DialogueText: I couldn't say, Captain. As much as I know, I've been leaving the land war to those that still see it as important.
I don't know, but if they did, they did it fast enough that we didn't hear about it.
We need to look for survivors as well, Captain. If we get lucky, we might even find a few.
All right, I don't like this one bit. And we're sitting ducks here without any knowledge of enemy fleet locations.
You didn't have to wait long, Captain! I see them there, against the horizon!
It's a trap! The Morganas leveled this whole town as bait. Send the men ashore for survivors and supplies. We'll hold them off.
An officer after my own heart. You heard the captain, dears! Look alive out there!
@BATTLE
We've only got a few minutes before the Morganas come at us again. What have we found?
It's very bad. Worse than Sherman's march to the sea. We've found maybe a dozen survivors, and most won't survive transit.
And the supplies? Have we found anything useful?
I know you're being pragmatic, Captain, but you don't need to sound so callous. A lady might get the wrong idea.
But yes, we've got a few boatloads of supplies, and we're taking them aboard now. What about the wounded?

Fields.MenuText: Leave them. Our resources are limited, and the ones who survive are safer inland in the long run anyway.
Try to get them all aboard. We can at least make their last hours comfortable.
Leave water and food for the dying and get the rest aboard. I want a full report on what happened.

Fields.DialogueText: Damn. By your orders, Captain. But I don't like it. We're supposed to be the human ones.
That's a tall order, darling, but my crew are up to it. They've seen enough death ashore as it is.
I'll see it done, Captain. I hate this war.
Give the order. We're going to buy as much time as we can before we have to break out or get bottled up.
On it, sweetie. Now let's give those wretched monsters a taste of their own medicine!
I certainly intend to.
@BATTLE
All right, Augusta, report. What happened back there? I need a clear picture.
I'm afraid I don't have one, Captain. What I've been able to piece together from a few photos one of the marines took was bad.
The state of the town indicates that the Morganas hit them in the morning, an hour or so before we were supposed to arrive.
They started a bombardment of the outskirts of town and set their sights further ashore as time went on.
Then the people had nowhere to go. They were just chewed to pieces by the shells.
Exactly, Captain. And they did it without warning, or any kind of demand.

Fields.MenuText: When we find the Morganas responsible, we can wring their miserable necks until they cough out an answer.
These people didn't deserve this. They had nothing to do with this war. With either war.
Maybe this will convince the next town to be more helpful.

Fields.DialogueText: Save some for me, darling. I'll show this monster how a proper Belle fights.
There are always civilian casualties in war, darling. It's what makes it so awful. If the only people who died in a war were those who wanted one, they'd be over instantly.
I somehow doubt this will go over well as a propaganda victory.
Someone's signaling from the bridge. It looks like we've got Morganas to the northwest.
No alarm this time, Captain?
Not until we figure out how they're tracking us.
@BATTLE
Captain, I've got it! I know how the Morganas knew where we were going to be!
Well, Augusta? I've got the entire Fleet running dark with silent radios, so I'd appreciate knowing what to change.
It's not us, darling, it's the listening posts! They've been broadcasting our locations to each other over the radio, and the Morganas have been listening.
All one has to do is understand German to be able to track our every move.
And yet they won't tell us where the Morgana fleets are. We're fighting blindfolded in a well-lit room.
Exactly. We need to have a talk with the fellow at the head of this organization.

Fields.MenuText: I can think of a few choice words to say to him myself.
We're going to have a rough time getting there with every Morgana fleet in the sea hunting us.
Are you sure it's even worth talking to him if he's been this actively detrimental to us?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, honey, let me. I am so very much the diplomat, after all. I will use gentle reasoning to help him.
Yes, but the longer they hunt us, the fewer civilians get raided. As long as we stay away from the resupply points.
Oh my, yes. I do believe I can have him cut that nonsense out lickety split.
Be thinking about what you want to say to him. It looks like we've got company in the meantime.
Time to deal with a few more foolish girls, I see.
@BATTLE
So while we have a minute, let's get back to Princess Augusta. Why is it making you so fidgety?
Come off it, darling. You don't want to hear about that. It's not nearly so much fun as the party we have coming up.
I mean it, Augusta. It seems like it's very important to you, and I want to know. But I won't press if it's too personal.
No, I suppose it's all right. I just don't like thinking about it. But you've earned a story, sweetie, and a glimpse into my mind.
Princess Augusta of Wales was a failure. She never made any impact on anything, and she died to be forgotten.
She didn't even know the language of the duchy she married into, and she never changed a single mind.
As a leader, as a statesman, and as a person, she was little more than a forgettable blip in history. At most, a name linking two kings.
And I have made it very clear to myself and to the world in general that I will be nothing like her.

Fields.MenuText: That's rough. I can certainly understand the bitterness. I didn't even know she existed.
Hey, you're nothing like her. You're strong, and powerful, and you're a large part of what keeps this fleet together.
You're right. That wasn't a very interesting story. I prefer you as the only Augusta.

Fields.DialogueText: Who does, these days? Her legacy is a garden somewhere, a few place names, and myself.
Thank you, sweetie. I know that, but it feels good to hear.
That's the nicest rude compliment I've ever received, you vagabond.
Now stow the deep and meaningful. We have a war to fight.
As you wish, your highness.
@BATTLE
Looks like the port is already under attack!
Push through to the docks and drive off the Morganas!
Aye, Captain!
... That sounds kind of strange coming from you.
*winks*
@BATTLE
That was rough, but it does appear that we have bought ourselves a bit of time.
Good. I'm going to have words with the man in charge of those listening posts.
Oh, honey, no. You have to let me do it. If you just call him a retrograde ignoramus who's dumber than a donkey walking backwards, we'll never get him to help us.
I assume, then, you'll be speaking to him in a quiet corner at a party you already have planned?
But of course, Captain! Nothing ever gets done at meetings, don't you see?

Fields.MenuText: I never cease to be amazed at how much change you can effect with a few quiet words and a glass of wine.
Who wouldn't do what you say when you're holding the second course hostage?
Truly, you are a master politician. You'll have to teach me your ways someday.

Fields.DialogueText: It's a gift, Captain. I am blessed in many ways, and this one is the most prominent.
That's why you always announce the dessert at the start of the meal, so everyone knows what they are keeping from themselves by being unreasonable.
I'll try, darling, but no one quite fills a formal dress like myself.
How did you deliver the invitations, anyway? That one still gets me, especially for a city under siege.
Why, Captain, it's obviously the penguins. They're perfect for insertions into hostile territory. Why else would I keep them around?
I am holding in my hand a rather interesting piece of paper, Augusta. Would you care to guess what it is?
Playing games with a lady's passion is undignified, Captain. Simply tell me or I shall be on my way.
All right, all right. It's a report from a certain German intelligence officer, and it has included a thorough update on Morgana positions and a vow of commitment.
Well, I imagine you're as happy as a cat with a saucer of cream then, aren't you darling?
It also contains a formal apology and a rather less formal request that his unmentionables not be ground up for schnitzel.
Rather crass of him to mention such things in formal communication, I feel. I know we're sailors, but we have class.
Do I want to know what you said to him at that party, Augusta?
No, Captain, you do not. It might shatter the façade I have so carefully crafted.

Fields.MenuText: I've said it before and I'll say it again, but your contributions to the Fleet are invaluable, Augusta. I don't know what we'd do without you.
Thank you. I could never grasp the vagaries of politicking and socializing the way you have.
Good job. I feel a lot better about our chances out there now.

Fields.DialogueText: Anything for you and my crew. And for my sisters in the Fleet.
The key is to stare menacingly while accidentally holding a carving knife just so.
Oh, darling, we were always going to win. This just ensures that the wicked girls will be rousted from every billet they find.
Still, it's good to know that whatever happens next, we're facing it together.
There's no Captain I'd rather have. No one else would ever have let me get away with that horse.
Hah, you're right about that. Wait, what horse?
Oh, just listen... the poor dear's spooked. I suppose duty sometimes whinnies.
@BATTLE
